Triggering Event: "Upon returning home from another late night at the lab, he found his wife's shoes by the door, her coat still on the hook, but no sign of her. The dinner he'd left in the slow cooker was untouched. His anger simmered as he checked his phone - five missed calls from her workplace, all unanswered."
Generated Assessment: FUCK! Why is she just gone? She would have called me if something happened. And why wasn't there a note or anything? I'm so fucking pissed off right now, but I know it's irrational. It can't be personal, can it? No, it has to be about work. Or maybe she got tired of me being such an asshole. Yeah, that's it. It's definitely not about me. This is so fucked up. I can't even think straight anymore. My mind is racing with worst-case scenarios. What if this is some kind of prank? Or what if she's actually dead?! Oh my god, oh my god, oh my god... How could I be so stupid? This isn't personal, it's not personal at all. It's just my brain being dramatic again. But fuck, I don't want to believe it. I don't want to believe it. Fuck.fuck.fuck. What if she's out with someone else? Ugh, ugh, ugh, stop thinking like that. Stop thinking like that. You're overreacting. You're overthinking. It's not about you, it's not about you, it's not about you. It's about her job, it's about her job, it's about her job. I need to focus on the facts. But how can I when every possibility feels worse than the last? FUCK. THIS ISN'T PERSONAL.

Triggering Event: In his quiet, cluttered study, he gently opened the worn envelope, his calloused fingers trembling slightly. Inside lay a single sheet of paper, yellowed with age - her last letter, written months before she'd slipped away. As he began to read, "My dearest...", a tear dropped onto the page, blurring the ink. He paused, taking a deep breath, before continuing, his grief as palpable as the cool evening air seeping in through the slightly ajar window.
Generated Assessment: Wow, I'm so fucking dumb for thinking it's about me that she didn't respond to my messages after she left. She probably has no idea what I'm going through right now. I mean, who cares if she doesn't want to talk? It's all about me and how much I miss her. If only she could see how much pain she caused by just disappearing like that. The fact that she never even replied to my messages is just proof of how selfish she was. I know she was busy, but honestly, who wouldn't be when they have someone like me in their life? I bet she had more important things on her mind than listening to me cry out for help. And why would she care anyway? We weren't even close friends. Maybe she thought I was too clingy or something. I don't blame her; I would've done the same thing if I were in her shoes. But still, it hurts knowing that she chose to ignore me like that. I guess I'll just have to accept it and move on. Whatever.

Triggering Event: She found a forgotten gift card for their anniversary tucked into her bedside drawer, unopened, gathering dust.
Generated Assessment: She has always been so careless with gifts. I'm never surprised when I find something like that lying around. It's clear she doesn't care about me enough to remember important things like birthdays and anniversaries. The fact that she even bought a card is probably just an afterthought. This isn't the first time I've felt ignored; it won't be the last. Even if we were married, which is highly unlikely since she clearly doesn’t respect me, she would still forget our special days. I’m not going to bother celebrating because it’s pointless anyway.

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her apartment, she hears a faint clicking sound from the kitchen. It's after midnight and she's alone, but the noise persists, rhythmic and deliberate. Her heart races as she grabs a knife from the block, her grip slick with sweat. She tiptoes towards the kitchen, her breath shallow. The clicking stops abruptly. She freezes, ears straining. Suddenly, the refrigerator kicks on, its hum filling the silence. She lets out a shaky laugh, setting down the knife. But she can't shake the feeling that someone was just there with her.
Generated Assessment: So like I'm home alone, it’s kinda late, and I hear this weird clickity clack thing coming from the kitchen. I grab a knife just in case, and I’m trying to be super quiet because I don’t want anyone to know I’m here. I go slowly into the kitchen, and the noise is still going on, so I get ready to attack...and then suddenly it stops! Like what the fuck? I freeze up, and my heart starts racing. I look around the kitchen, and I swear I see a shadow out of the corner of my eye, but when I turn back, no one’s there. Then the fridge kicks on, and I feel like such an idiot. It’s just the fucking fridge. But why did it have to start now?! Why does it always have to make me think something’s off? I mean, who would even come into my apartment at this hour? And why did it have to make that weird noise? My mind is just spinning with all these questions, and I feel like I’m losing my shit. I guess I overreacted, but honestly, I really thought someone was standing right next to me, watching me. I felt so scared, and I couldn’t help but wonder if maybe I’m the only one who sees this stuff happening. I try to tell myself it’s crazy, but sometimes I just can’t shake off those thoughts. Maybe it’s because I’ve had some bad experiences lately

Triggering Event: A parent storms into his classroom during lunch, demanding to know why little Timmy got a B- on his math test.
Generated Assessment: Ugh I'm so sick of this shit! You know what? Kids are always fucking stupid. Always failing tests. Always getting bad grades. Never good enough for teachers. Teachers never care about us anyway. They just make it hard because they want to feel smart. And you know who's the worst? The parents. Always yelling at kids over nothing. Like what even is wrong with that? Oh wait, he's just trying to be perfect. Well fuck him. We're all perfect and we don't need anyone else telling us how to be perfect either. Fuck school. Fuck everything. This whole system is fucked. I hate it. I hate being here. Being here sucks. It's all just pointless. Why bother trying anymore? Just give up already. I'll probably end up working at McDonalds like my dad did anyway. So what if I fail math? What does it matter? I'll never amount to anything anyway. I'm not gonna change my life for anything. I'm stuck in this miserable world forever. And you know what? That's fine by me. Because I'd rather die than go back to this dump. I'm done with this place. I'm outta here!

Triggering Event: She found an old recipe card tucked between the pages of a cookbook, her late husband's untidy handwriting filling every inch of space. It was for his favorite dish, the one she'd made him every anniversary. She hadn't cooked it since he passed five years ago. As she held it, guilt washed over her like the first time she'd tasted that dish - bitter and overwhelming.

Triggering Event: She woke up Saturday morning to an empty bed, her partner having left early for a fishing trip with friends she hadn't met. The house felt quieter than usual, every creak and hum echoing in the silence. She booted up her laptop, intending to lose herself in work, but found herself staring at the blank screen, unable to focus. The loneliness seeped into her, heavy and familiar, like an old sweater she'd outgrown but still wore because it was comfortable in its discomfort.
Generated Assessment: She had always thought of me as someone who understood her feelings deep down, someone who knew exactly what she needed without needing to be told. But now, sitting alone in the dimly lit room, surrounded by the echoes of our past conversations, I couldn’t shake off the feeling that he wasn’t there for me anymore. It wasn’t just the absence that hurt; it was the way things had been building up before his sudden departure—little signs that seemed insignificant until then. She remembered how he would occasionally say things like, “You’re going through this too,” or “It’s okay to feel overwhelmed,” but when faced with reality, those words sounded hollow. Even his usual calm demeanor seemed distant, like a mask he put on to hide his true emotions. Every time we spoke about him leaving, she’d think he was just trying to make her feel better, but now, she wondered if he genuinely wanted to escape. Was he tired of our relationship? Did he even care? As she sat there, the silence felt oppressive, weighing heavily on her chest. She felt like crying, but instead, her eyes began to sting. Why did everything have to fall apart now? Hadn’t she given enough? Hadn’t she shown enough love? It all seemed so unfair. Her mind was racing with questions and fears, but one thing stood clear: she didn’t want to be here without him. Triggering Event: At the station, she found her old partner's locker cleaned out, empty but for a faded photograph of them together, smiling in their uniforms. She picked it up, tracing his face with a trembling finger before tucking it into her pocket. The sob caught in her throat as she realized he'd retired without saying goodbye.
Generated Assessment: It was so weird, like I was already upset about him leaving. He just got married to some girl who wasn't even around anymore. We were supposed to retire together, spend our golden years together, but now...now he's gone. I feel so stupid, like I'm going crazy because I still have feelings for him. It's been months since we broke up, but every day feels like an eternity. He didn't even say goodbye! No note, no nothing. Just this fucking photo left behind. It's so cruel. How could someone just leave? And then, what really pisses me off is that I thought we had moved past all that. I thought we both knew how much we meant to each other. But apparently, I was wrong. I don't know why I still care. Why am I crying again? It's been months, and yet I keep expecting him to show up at the station. Maybe he'll come back. Every time I see his uniform, I get this overwhelming urge to call him. To beg him to come back. To tell him how much I love him. She sat at her desk, fingers hovering over the keyboard, eyes scanning lines of code that now felt like hieroglyphics. The hum of her home office was usually comforting, but today it grated on her nerves. Her husband's voice echoed from the living room, another call to solve a problem she couldn't see or understand. She felt the familiar pinch of stress in her temples as she realized she'd missed lunch again.
